desc.size: Large tree to 20 - 30 m tall, trunk diameter 0.5 - 1.2 m. Trunk commonly divided into a few large trunks, and forked into many spreading branches with drooping ends, which form a broad, rounded, flat-topped, or vase-shaped crown.

part.partText: ashy gray, thick, furrowed into broad, interlacing, scaly ridges; with alternating light and dark colored bands in cross section.
slender, firm, light green, becoming ashy gray; smooth or sparsely hairy. Leaf scars half-round, covered with a corky layer, having 3 bundle scars.
reddish brown, 3 - 6 mm long, broadly egg-shaped, blunt to pointed, flattened, smooth or slightly hairy.

alternate, with short, stout, yellowish leafstalks; dark green and sometimes rough above, pale and usually softly hairy beneath; 10 - 15 cm long, half as wide, oval to elliptic, base asymmetrical, tip pointed, margins coarsely doubly-toothed, thick, firm, veins rarely forked. Leaves turning yellow in autumn. Note: leaf morphology is highly variable for this species.

single-seeded, winged (samara); in crowded clusters; long-stalked, 1.2 cm long, oval, margin hairy, tip deeply notched.

similarSpecies.comments: Ulmus procera has smaller leaves (5 - 8 cm long) and hairless samaras. Ulmus pumila also has smaller leaves (3 - 7 cm long), which are not distinctly asymmetrical at the base or doubly-toothed. Ulmus rubra has very rough leaves, forked veins near the leaf margin, rusty-colored bud hairs, and brown, hairy seed cavities. Ulmus thomasii has corky wings on the twigs, leaves with a nearly symmetrical base, and hairy samaras. Characteristics of the hybrid U. x notha are intermediate of the two parents, U. pumila and U. rubra. The most distinctive features are the middle bud scales fringed with white hairs and the terminal scales fringed with reddish brown hairs. Celtis leaves, which are similar in appearance, have three main veins arising from the base of each blade.

speciesPage.flowering: March to mid-May, before the leaves.
speciesPage.habitatEcology: Common in rich woods, wooded floodplains, and along streams, but can be found in a wide variety of soil types.

notes.comments: Ulmus americana is frequently planted as an ornamental and shade tree. Because of its attractive vase-shaped branching, this species was planted extensively along town and city streets by early Europeans, forming beautiful cathedral-like avenues. Since the mid-1950’s, both the street plantings and the wild populations in the Chicago Region have been severely decimated by Dutch elm disease and phloem necrosis. Today, disease-resistant clones and hybrids are available for planting. The wood of Ulmus americana is used for furniture, flooring, boxes, crates, barrels, veneer, and shipbuilding. See link to Dutch elm disease below.

etymology.comments: Ulmus is the Latin word for elm. Americana means “of or from America” (North or South).
